 If QM isn't giving you a headache than you aren't thinking about it hard enough. The fact that you have difficulty means you're on the right track. The problem is that QM tells us that the universe operates in a way which is contrary to what we call common sense. What this experiment is illustrating is the operation of probability waves. In the "real" macroscopic world, if I throw a ball to you we're used to thinking that the ball follows a certain path. We could draw a line, and at any point in time the ball would be somewhere on that line, and no where else. In QM you can't say that something is definately in one place. If I shoot an electron at a target I can't just draw a line and say that the electron in somewhere on that line. The best we can do is say what the probability is that it's somewhere. This isn't just a matter of us not having good enough testing equipment. The electron is, for all purposes, a probability wave, distributed over space. Until we actually do something that would confirm or deny that it's in a particular spot, it isn't really anywhere specific. For macroscopic objects that probabilities are such that the odds of you being where it looks like you are are 99.(lots of 9s)%, so I'm not sure if the cat is meant to be an illustration or if it's actually supposed to be both dead and alive until its probability wave is collapsed.

 Suppose you insert an electron into a box. Common sense tells us that the electron must have a definite location even if we don't know where it is.
 
 If the electron exists as a wave filling the box, it could exist anywhere (or everywhere?) inside.
 
 The moment we open the box, the wave function collapses at a certain location.
 
 Suppose we partition the box into two equal areas without looking. Common sense then tells us that the electron must be in one half of the box. But as long as we don't observe it, the electron wave still occupies both halves of the box. It only collapses on one side of the partition when we look inside.
 
 As long as we don't look, we could move the two halves of the box light years apart and the electron wave still occupies both boxes. 
 
 The probability wave will only collapse and the electron 'decide' which box it occupies, when we open one of them.

 Well, this is the philosophical problem with quantum physics. Essentially, the problem of observation comes back to the difficulty of understanding that particles literally exist as probabilistic waves until we measure them. They do not have an objective existence. No one knows why this is the case any more than we know why gravity exists. 
 
 Remember science doesn't ask why?, it asks how? and what?. I'm not trying to be patronising; it's easy to forget this when learning about the strange quantum world. All our results in classical physics make intuitive sense because they deal with the world we perceive. Classical theory makes sense because it describes accurately phenomena we already know about. Quantum theory describes things that we can never see, that we didn't even know existed until the 20th century.
 
 So asking "How can the observer have any effect on the objective reality of what he observes ?" is doomed to failure, all we know is that it does. The two-slit experiment proves it conclusively: When we position a detector at one of the slits, there is no interference pattern because the particle is 'forced to choose' a path; when there is no detector, or the detector is switched off, an interference pattern is produced because the particle goes through both slits at once and interferes with itself. There's no way around it. 
 
 It gets even weirder: if the detector is precisely timed to switch on and perform a measurement after the particle has gone through the slits, we still find that the interference pattern disappears, so the particle has suddenly 'decided' to behave not like a spread-out wave, but a particle that has only gone through one of the slits. 
 
 With your electron-in-a-box example, you can either say that the electron exists as a wavefunction that occupies both halves of the box until you check; or you can say that the electron has no objective reality until you check. It comes to the same thing. It is a paradoxical problem that we can never actually observe a wavefunction, because of course the act of observation collapses the wave function. But we can infer its reality through the different results given by the two-slits experiment, and I'm sure a knowledgeable physicist would be able to think up an experiment that prove it in the electron-in-a-box scenario. If it weren't for the strange results of quantum experiments like these, it would be possible to leave it to philosophy, but in fact we find that actual reality doesn't make any sense.
 
 We have to accept the results even though we can't conceptualise the reality of what's going on in the experiment. As for being "utterly bizarre, even mad", nobody disagrees.  Crazy, isn't it?

Of course we then have the added problem that the electron could tunnel out of the box at any moment. It's also pretty much impossible to know whether a particle is there without detecting it, often by it decaying into radiation, or other particles, or by it colliding with something else.

Thinking about it, isn't Schrodinger's Cat and Quantum Tunneling also proof that there isn't an omniscient obsever?
